Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the instrumentality rule for determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, a plaintiff must prove: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.

Headnote: Under California law, a corporation's acts or obligations can be legally recognized as those of a particular person if: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, that is, adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Saks Management and Associates, LLC v. Sung General Contracting, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Because the cardinal rule of corporate law is that a corporation possesses a legal existence separate and apart from that of its officers and shareholders, the mere operation of corporate business does not render one personally liable for corporate acts; in order to pierce the corporate veil, there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form, and the plaintiff must show that the defendant disregarded the separateness of legal entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties, records, or control.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Industry Regulation. Repair rule exemption to ban on unlicensed contractors from enforcing construction contracts did not allow contractor to enforce contract.

Title: Roley v. National Professional Exchange, Inc.

Headnote: Under Maryland law, courts apply the alter ego doctrine for piercing the corporate veil only in exceptional circumstances, when the plaintiff shows: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.

Title: Thornton v. Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, a plaintiff must show the following three elements to justify piercing the corporate veil under the alter ego theory: (1) the dominant party must have complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy and business practices so that at the time of the attacked transaction the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) the control must have been misused by the dominant party, and although fraud or the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty is misuse of the control, when it is necessary to prevent injustice or inequitable circumstances, misuse of control will be presumed; and (3) the misuse of this control proximately caused the harm or unjust loss complained of.

Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil involves an examination of the defendant's relationship to the corporation and requires the court to determine whether there exists proof of three elements: (1) control by the defendant, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Title: In re Trujillo

Headnote: Under Florida law, to pierce the corporate veil, three factors must be satisfied: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.

Title: Sedgwick Properties Development Corporation v. Hinds

Headnote: To determine whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil, a court must conduct a three-part inquiry; first, the court must determine whether the corporate entity is the alter ego of the person or entity in issue, second, it must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form, because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, and, third, the court must consider whether an equitable result will be achieved by disregarding the corporate form and holding a shareholder or other insider personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alleged undercapitalization of limited liability company (LLC) did not support piercing LLC's corporate veil in garnishment action.

Title: MCI Telecommunications Corp. v. O'Brien Marketing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under federal common-law alter ego rule, corporate form may be disregarded in interests of justice when it is used to defeat overriding public policy.
Document Preview: Long-distance telephone company brought action against corporate customer, which was telemarketer, to recover unpaid charges for interstate telecommunication services provided to customer.  After entry of judgment for company and award of attorney fees to company, company moved to institute proceedings supplementary, and order was issued requiring corporation to show cause why it should not be impleaded as party, as alter ego of customer.  Upon corporation's failure to respond to show cause order, corporation was impleaded as party.  The District Court, Highsmith, J., held that: (1) federal law, rather than state law, applied to issue of piercing the corporate veil, and (2) piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate and, thus, corporation was liable, as alter ego of customer, for final judgment for unpaid charges and for attorney fees and costs. Ordered accordingly.

Document Preview: Divorce. Order granting motion to clarify divorce decree was impermissible order amending division of property.

Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.

Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under Florida law only when it is apparent that corporation was mere device, sham, or alter ego of another corporation or individual who owns controlling share of corporation in question.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under Florida law when corporation was used to evade some statute or to accomplish some fraud or illegal purpose, and fraud will be presumed when there is self-dealing or the legal effect of transaction is to delay or hinder creditors.
Document Preview: DISCOVERY. additional discovery on issue of whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to hold parent of corporation liable to asbestos claimants was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Cooper
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Criteria for piercing corporate veil under nonbankruptcy law are generally that shareholders disregarded corporate entity and made it mere instrumentality for their own affairs, there is such unity of interest in ownership that owners and corporation have no separate existence, and upholding corporate veil would protect fraud or promote other injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Fidelity & Deposit Co. of Maryland v. Commercial Cas. Consultants, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporate veil is pierced when corporation is alter ego of its owners or shareholders, corporation is used for illegal purpose, and corporation is used as sham to perpetuate a fraud. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A.
Document Preview: Insurer brought cause of action against, inter alia, shareholders of insurance agency, seeking to hold them personally responsible for agency's debt on theory that corporate entity should be disregarded and that the shareholders knowingly breached a fiduciary duty to insurer.  Following a jury trial, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas at San Antonio, Dorwin W. Suttle, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and shareholders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, W. Eugene Davis, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence was not sufficient to hold the shareholders liable on theory of disregard or piercing the corporate veil; (2) evidence was sufficient to hold the shareholders liable on theory of knowingly participating in breach of fiduciary duty; and (3) insurer was not entitled to award of attorney fees. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Alpert v. Bertsch

Title: Detrick v. Midwest Pipe & Steel, Inc.

The Court of Appeals, Staton, J., held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment of issue of whether trucker was independent contractor or employee subject to shipper's control; (2) fact issues precluded summary judgment on issue of whether shipper was estopped from denying status as trucker's employer; (3) shipper could not be held vicariously liable as matter of law pursuant to ICC regulations for driver's negligence; (4) fact issue precluded summary judgment on claim that trucking firm existed as alter ego or mere instrumentality of shipper; and (5) shipper could not be held liable for negligence in failing to ascertain that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: New Jersey Dept. of Environmental Protection v. Gloucester Environmental Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under New Jersey law, evidence must be presented to show that corporation is a "sham" which exists to avoid personal liability of officers.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against corporate owners of landfill and shareholders of corporation under the New Jersey Sanitary Landfill Facility Closure and Contingency Fund Act (SFCCFA).  On shareholders' motion for partial summary judgment dismissing of claims asserted against them, the District Court, Brotman, J., held that: (1) shareholder who owns less than majority share of corporate operator of landfill may be held liable as operator under the SFCCFA where shareholder shows high degree of personal involvement in operation and decision-making process of corporation, but (2) genuine issues of material fact existed, precluding summary judgment. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: 111 Properties, Inc. v. Lassiter
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: For corporate veil of corporation formed to purchase property to be pierced to reach individually the sole shareholder of the corporation, vendor needed to demonstrate existence of improper conduct in formation or use of the corporation.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action against purchaser corporation and corporation's sole stockholder for breach of contract and fraud.  The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Thomas Johnson, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Gunther, J., held that: (1) even if formation of corporation was subterfuge to conceal identity of purchaser from vendor, that was not ground for piercing corporate veil, and (2) purchaser corporation did not breach agreement to assist vendor in collecting back taxes and back rent from tenant where tenant was insolvent and any effort to collect would have been futile. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: M & M Wholesale Florist, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Following factors are to be considered when determining whether to disregard corporate form: inadequacy of capital; fraudulent purpose in conception or operation of business; or operation of corporation as instrumentality or alter ego.
Document Preview: Supplier brought action to recover on account of corporate flower shop, seeking to hold corporation's owners individually liable.  The Circuit Court, Baldwin County, No. CV90653, Charles C. Partin, J., entered summary judgment in favor of owners, and supplier appealed. The Supreme Court, Ingram, J., held that evidence that owner opened account with supplier while her flower shop was a sole proprietorship and that supplier was never informed that flower shop was subsequently incorporated was insufficient to pierce corporate veil and hold owner liable for corporation's debt. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Swall v. Custom Automotive Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To satisfy two-pronged test for determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: President and vice president of corporation were held personally liable for corporate debt to consignor in the Clay County Circuit Court, Frank D. Connett, Jr., J., and president and vice president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ulrich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required for piercing corporate veil, and (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was undercapitalized and that president and vice president stripped corporation's assets in reckless disregard of consignor's legal rights as required for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Fitzgerald v. Pratt
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Separate identities of corporation and its shareholders, directors and officers may be disregarded in situations where it would otherwise pose obstacle to protection or enforcement of private or public rights. S.H.A. ch. 32, ¶ 415-8.
Document Preview: Employee brought action based on alleged sexual harassment against coemployee and her former employer's successor corporation.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, Nicholas G. Byron, J., dismissed action pursuant to exclusive remedy provision of the Workers' Compensation Act, and employee appealed.  The Appellate Court, Howerton, J., held that: (1) employee's intentional tort claims against coemployee were not barred by exclusive remedy provision, but (2) professional corporation's successor did not assume predecessor's liability, under alter ego theory, for intentional torts committed by corporate employee that were not in furtherance of predecessor's business. Affirmed in part; reversed in part and remanded. Goldenhersh, P.J., filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Title: Schlater v. Haynie

The Court of Appeals, Todd, P.J., held that: (1) fact that corporation's lessor was unable to collect delinquent rent under lease with corporation which became insolvent because of unprofitable operations during which all of corporation's assets had been pledged to bank to obtain operating funds was alone insufficient to establish liability for corporation's debt to lessor on part of officers and stockholders, even though they formed second corporation in another state and used some of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Stamp v. Inamed Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Courts will disregard corporate entity if necessary to further interests of public convenience, fairness, and equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: First Health, Inc. v. Blanton
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded and limited stockholder liability denied if there is inadequacy of capital, fraudulent purpose in conception or operation of business, or operation of corporation as instrumentality or alter ego, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil will be pierced.

The Circuit Court, Lawrence County, No. CV89109, A. Philip Reich, II, J., entered judgment for physician, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kennedy, J., held that absent any showing that corporation which controlled stock in hospital misused its control, or that physician's loss of wages resulted from misuse of that control, corporate entity would not be disregarded. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Cleghorn v. Ferron Metalcraft

Title: Consun Food Industries, Inc. v. Fowkes

Title: Husky Spray Service, Inc. v. Patzer

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Coastal Shutters and Insulation, Inc. v. Derr
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego is only one basis for disregarding the corporation fiction, which will also be disregarded when fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud, is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation, is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, is used to circumvent statute, or is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong, or where corporation is undercapitalized.
Document Preview: In suit against corporation and its president to collect on note and extensions thereof, the 56th District Court, Galveston County, H.G. Dalehite, J., rendered judgment in holder's favor. Affirmed. Murphy, J., concurred in part and dissented in part and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. WRW Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Kentucky, London Division. .
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporation ordinarily is regarded as separate from individuals comprising it, but corporate persona is not inviolate; when separate legal entity is used to justify wrong, protect fraud, or subvert public policy, then corporate veil should be pierced and association of persons making up corporation should be held responsible for corporation's financial liabilities.
Document Preview: United States sued mining corporation and its principals to collect unpaid civil penalties assessed against corporation for violations of Federal Mine Safety and Health Act.  United States moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Siler, C.J., held that: (1) administrative law judge's decision that corporation was mine operator and was liable for civil penalty assessment was final and unappealable, and (2) corporate veil would be pierced to hold principals personally liable. Motion granted. See also 731 F.Supp. 237.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Huntsville Aviation Corp. v. Ford

Headnote: Corporation's separate existence will ordinarily be recognized so that liability for corporation's debt will be limited to corporate assets.

The Supreme Court, Almon, J., held that: (1) whether sole shareholder was alter ego of subtenant was fact question; (2) whether tenant was third-party beneficiary to contract between controlled corporation and airport authority for expansion of hangar was fact question; and (3) whether shareholder fraudulently promised to be personally liable for amount owed on hangar was fact question. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Trans Pacific Ins. Co. v. Trans-Pacific Ins. Co.

The District Court, Waldman, J., held that: (1) plaintiff was entitled to add corporate defendants; (2) plaintiff showed good cause for extension of time in which to serve additional defendants; (3) defendant was not entitled to protective order; (4) plaintiff was not entitled to order compelling deposition; and (5) chief financial officer of defendant could be compelled to attend deposition. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Sky Lake Gardens Recreation, Inc. v. Sky Lake Gardens Nos. 1, 3, and 4, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Ohio Bur. of Workers' Comp. v. Widenmeyer Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Concept that corporation is a legal entity, separate and apart from natural persons who compose it, is a legal fiction designed to facilitate transacting of business; however, where corporate form is used to subvert intent and policy of legal fiction, fiction should be disregarded and corporation considered a collection of individuals.
Document Preview: After Bureau of Workers' Compensation obtained a judgment against corporation for unpaid workers' compensation premiums and penalties, it filed complaint alleging that second corporation was successor to first corporation, and that employee and officer were alter egos of first corporation, rendering them liable for judgment. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Dent Gitchel, Special Justice, held that: (1) trial court's error in entering summary judgment in favor of hospital's parent corporation was harmless; (2) plaintiffs were not prejudiced by trial court's refusal to strike juror for cause; (3) statute governing procedure to be followed when jury desires further instruction during deliberation was violated, but there was no prejudice; (4) failure to question verdict before jury was discharged waived claim that verdict was result of jury...

Title: Manville Sales Corp. v. Paramount Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Court may exert its equitable powers and disregard corporate entity if court decides that piercing corporate veil will prevent fraud, illegality, injustice, contravention of public policy, or prevent corporation from shielding someone from criminal liability.
Document Preview: Holder of patent for iris guide arms for self-centering luminaire assembly designed to be used on lighting poles brought action against another corporation and its corporate officers, alleging infringement. Affirmed in part;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Jarax Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Although use of corporation has long been recognized as lawful means of limiting liability, to retain corporate veil, there must be some independence and something at risk, and creditors of subsidiary must not be misled as to with whom they are dealing or upon whom they are relying.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Major Funding Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In Texas, corporate fiction will not be disregarded to hold officer liable unless it is apparent that officer was using corporate form as conduit for violation of important principles of public policy.

The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) bankruptcy trustee that had not sufficiently pled or proved he had standing to pursue cause of action to avoid transfer voidable by creditor holding unsecured claim was precluded from recovering by means of state law causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, negligence, assumpsit, and money had and received, and (2) evidence supported finding that principal controlled corporate debtor and its finances and had intent to defraud in transactions in which principal intentionally used corporate funds for his and/or his family's personal benefit, thus supporting avoidance of such transfers as fraudulent. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Itel Containers Intern. Corp. v. Atlanttrafik Exp. Service Ltd.

The Court of Appeals, Kearse, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporation was not joint venturer with holding company formed to purchase shipping line; (2) holding company was not actual or implied agent of corporation; (3) corporation did not exercise sufficient control over holding company to warrant piercing of corporate veil; but (4) dismissing lessors' maritime lien claims against vessels without making findings of facts and conclusions of law, required vacation of judgment dismissing the claims. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Murat v. F/V Shelikof Strait
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.

The Supreme Court, Burke, J., held that: (1) direct service on corporate officers was adequate to satisfy corporation's due process rights even though attorney of record was not served; (2) fishermen's pleading adequately informed officer that personal liability would be sought on corporate debt; and (3) issues of material fact existed on whether officer could be held personally liable for corporate debts. Affirmed in part; reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >

Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced when corporate entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud or defend crime.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Bailey
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.

Document Preview: In Chapter 11 case of individual debtors, claims were asserted by entities with claims against corporation that was owned entirely by one of the debtors. The Bankruptcy Court, Alexander L. Paskay, Chief Judge, held that corporate entity would be disregarded and personal liability imposed upon debtors due to improper conduct of debtors in forming corporation with specific intention of circumventing cease-and-desist order issued by federal agency to preexisting corporation and persons involved with it. Claims allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Joslyn Mfg. Co. v. T.L. James & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Veil piercing should be limited to situations in which corporate entity is used as sham to perpetrate fraud or avoid personal liability.
Document Preview: Corporation ordered to clean up contaminated site of former wood treating and/or creosoting operation initiated action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act and Louisiana Environmental Quality Act.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, Shreveport Division, Tom Stagg, Chief Judge, 696 F.Supp. 222, entered summary judgment for defendants, and corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the Acts did not impose direct liability on parent corporations for violations of their wholly owned subsidiaries, and (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced to impose liability on the parent corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Esmark, Inc. v. N.L.R.B.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil will only be pierced to protect interests of third party; separate corporate entity will not be disregarded to allow corporation to escape its obligations.
Document Preview: Parent corporation petitioned for review of order of National Labor Relations Board finding parent liable for unfair labor practices of subsidiaries. Board filed cross application for enforcement of order. The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) limitation period for filing unfair labor practices charge by union did not commence on date union received formal notice of plant closure; (2) repudiation of master agreement, after only two-week hiatus in operations of plant, was sufficient to show discrimination in employment based upon union activities or affiliation without showing of the antiunion animus; (3) remand for determination of whether employer could be found liable on basis of direct control for unfair labor practices of subsidiaries was required. Petition for review granted, cross application denied and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Aero Planning Intern., Inc. v. Air Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, judgment creditor of corporation must make prima facie showing that individual defendants controlled corporations, that they engaged in improper conduct in their exercise of control, and that their improper conduct caused creditor's inability to obtain adequate remedy from corporation.
Document Preview: After judgment creditor received judgment against corporations for breach of contract, and was unable to collect upon it, creditor amended its complaint to add corporation's shareholders as parties.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Donald Londer, J., granted shareholders' motion to dismiss and entered judgment in their favor, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Newman, J., held that creditor failed to make prima facie showing of improper conduct by shareholders in exercise of control over corporations, and thus corporations' corporate veil would not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for judgment against corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Pan Eastern Exploration Co. v. Hufo Oils
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under Texas law, where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of other corporation, where corporate form is used to avoid legal limitations on natural persons or corporations, or where form is used as sham to perpetrate fraud, inequity or injustice.
Document Preview: Natural gas company and its wholly owned subsidiary filed suit against oil producers and other defendants based on defendants' alleged conversion of natural gas belonging to plaintiffs.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment on jury verdict which rejected all of parties' claims, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) finding that managers of gas company and its wholly owned affiliate had consented to independent oil producer's alleged conversion of affiliate's gas, by signing agreement to purchase oil producer's casinghead gas even though they suspected that producer had obtained gas by high-level perforation of gas formations to which affiliate held rights, was sufficiently supported by evidence, and (2) consent continued, at very latest, until plaintiffs filed suit against producer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Title: In re Vermont Toy Works, Inc.

Conrad, J., held that: (1) trustee had standing as hypothetical judicial lien creditor to affirmatively raise equitable doctrine of marshaling; (2) unsecured creditor's attorney could prosecute on behalf of trustee contested matter with trustee's consent and court's approval; (3) inequitable conduct of debtor's director, officer and shareholder was sufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil and application of marshaling of assets doctrine; and (4) after marshaling, debtor's director, officer, and shareholder's inequitable conduct required equitable...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Messick v. Moring
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Although limitation of personal liability is valid corporate attribute, corporate entity will be disregarded when it is used solely to avoid personal liability of owner while reserving to owner benefits gained through use of corporate name.
Document Preview: Executor of estate of automobile driver killed in automobile accident brought dram shop and wrongful death action against three corporations and against stockholders, officers and directors of corporations individually.  The Circuit Court, Mobile County, Telfair J. Mashburn, J., entered summary judgment relieving stockholders and directors of all personal liability, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that write off of loan of $112,000 to stockholders as bad debt, with no effort to collect, and transfer of money into stock brokerage account without any documentation were insufficient to establish excessive control of corporation by stockholders so as to warrant imposition of personal liability on stockholders for corporation's debts. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Terre Du Lac Ass'n, Inc. v. Terre Du Lac, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Test for piercing the corporate veil is two-pronged: corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Homeowners' association brought action against subdivision developer, and other corporate defendants and individuals, including financier of development, seeking specific enforcement of alleged promises concerning roads, common areas and amenities, damages for breach of contract and declaratory relief.  The Circuit Court, Cape Girardeau County, A.J. Seier, J., granted motion to dismiss and association appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) dismissal of prior federal court action was not res judicata as to state court claims; (2) association was proper party to bring action to enforce purchase contracts between its members and developer; (3) association failed to state claim against financier; and (4) allegation that controlling corporation was alter ego of other defendant corporations was sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Title: J.L. Brock Builders, Inc. v. Dahlbeck
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Corporation will generally be looked upon as legal entity, and until sufficient reason to contrary appears, but, when notion of real entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, law will regard corporation as an association of persons.

Reversed and remanded with direction. Krivosha, C.J., filed dissenting opinion.

Title: ServiceMaster Industries Inc. v. J.R.L. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: When the notion of a corporation as a complete and separate entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, project fraud, or defend crime, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.

At commencement of trial, parties stipulated that licensee had underreported revenues attributable to the license and to a judgment against the licensee in the sum of $40,000.  Trial then proceeded only as to shareholder.  The District Court, Douglas County, John E. Clark, J., entered judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Boslaugh, J., held that evidence was not clear and convincing that defendant submitted revenue reports knowing representations to be false or that he acted recklessly without knowledge as to the truth of the representations. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Matter of Reading Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts will not allow corporate form to be used to defeat public policy, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud, but will look beyond that form as justice may require.
Document Preview: Prereorganization petition of reorganized railroad to both disaffirm lease and collect damages for breach of lease came before court. The District Court, Ditter, J., held that: (1) basis for ignoring corporate distinction between reorganized railroad and another railroad which would permit reorganized railroad to reject lease entered into by other railroad did not exist, and (2) reorganization court lacked jurisdiction to consider reorganized railroad's claims that lessee breached provisions of lease of which it was third-party beneficiary. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Rose v. Intercontinental Bank, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Generally, court will not disregard corporate fiction and hold individual liable unless corporate entity is employed to defraud existing creditors, to circumvent statute, to evade existing obligation, to protect crimes, or to achieve or perpetuate monopoly.

The Court of Appeals, Hoyt, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to establish that officer/shareholder showed bad faith such as to render him liable under alter-ego doctrine; (2) evidence of witness' alleged criminal conduct was not admissible; and (3) witness could not give personal opinion as to officer/shareholder's character. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >

The District Court, Edward C. Title: Branscum v. Castleberry

Headnote: Exception to general rule that forbids ignoring corporate existence exists only in extreme situations where party proves that the sole purpose of the corporation is to perpetuate fraud against the public or against public policy such as to achieve a monopoly, to circumvent a statute, or to protect crime.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Branscum v. Castleberry
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Corporation is creature apart from its shareholders and should not be ignored by courts unless public necessity exists to sacrifice the corporate entity so that some accepted public policy may be upheld or defended.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Roy E. Thomas Const. Co. v. Arbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: The corporate fiction will be disregarded when it is used as a means for perpetrating fraud, when the corporation is organized and operated as the mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, where resort is made to the corporate fiction in order to avoid an existing legal obligation, when the corporate form is used to achieve or perpetuate monopoly, when the corporate structure is used as a vehicle for circumventing a statute or when the fiction is invoked in order to protect crime or justify wrong.

Affirmed in part and reversed and reformed in part.

Husband appealed. Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Headnote: An individual defendant will be held jointly and severally liable where he is the sole shareholder of a defendant corporation, its "alter ego" and the guiding spirit and the active directing hand in full charge of the corporate operation. In such case whenever justice or public policy demands it, the court will pierce the corporate veil and disregard the fiction that a corporation must be a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: People ex rel. Brown v. Illinois State Troopers Lodge No. 41
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.
Headnote: Courts are hesitant to disregard corporate entity unless circumstances strongly warrant such action; however, corporate veil will be pierced in order to prevent evasion of statutory or constitutional duty imposed by the state.
Document Preview: The state, on the relation of director of Department of Law Enforcement, brought action against nonprofit corporation to enjoin the corporation from using name Illinois State Trooper in solicitation campaigns and to enjoin violation of certain departmental rules. The Circuit Court, Sangamon County, Creel Douglass, J., dismissed the complaint and the state appealed. The Appellate Court, Smith, J., held that complaint was sufficient to state cause of action for application of rules proscribing solicitation by police officers to corporation all of whose members were members of state highway police, and that use of phrase Illinois State Trooper could only cause confusion and create impression that state agency or department was in some manner connected with corporation's solication and, therefore, corporation's use of phrase was in violation of statute. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Casanova Guns, Inc. v. Connally
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Fiction of a corporate entity must be disregarded if it has been adopted or used to circumvent the provisions of a statute.
Document Preview: Proceeding in review of State Regional Commissioner of Treasury Department's Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms Division's denial of application for renewal of federal firearms license. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, Robert E. Tehan, J., upheld Commissioner's decision, and licensee appealed. The Court of Appeals held that finding by Commissioner that corporation, which was a convicted felon, controlled or had power to control licensee and thus that licensee was not entitled to renewal of its license was not clearly erroneous. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: N. L. R. B. v. Miller Trucking Service, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: The corporate entity will sometimes be pierced when it is used to evade legal responsibility, but it will not be pierced to protect it against its own wrongdoing.
Document Preview: Proceeding on application for enforcement of order of the National Labor Relations Board. The Court of Appeals, Breitenstein, Circuit Judge, held that NLRB determination that employer's interrogation of five out of ten employees with no communication of purpose of interrogation and with no assurance against reprisals and employer's threat of reprisal in regard to vacation pay for one employee had substantial impact on employees' ability to continue to exercise organizational rights would not be accepted in absence of findings as to extensiveness of the unfair practices in terms of their past effect and likelihood of recurrence. Enforcement denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Bruhn's Freezer Meats of Chicago, Inc. v. U. S. Dept. of Agriculture
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded when failure to do so would enable corporate device to be used to circumvent statute.
Document Preview: Proceeding on petition to review decision of judicial officer of Department of Agriculture finding that petitioners, freezer plant operators, had engaged in practices violating Packers and Stockyards Act. The Court of Appeals, Matthes, Chief Judge, held, inter alia, freezer plant operators who, in commerce, cut up sides and quarters of beef into consumer cuts, boned and ground meats, and then trimmed and wrapped individual cuts and froze prepared meat to preserve it, were engaged in preparing meats, and were thus packers' within Packers and Stockyards Act. Affirmed.

Title: Family Center Drug Store, Inc. v. North Dakota State Bd. of Pharmacy

Headnote: A corporation will be looked on as a legal entity as a general rule, and until sufficient reason to the contrary appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend, the corporate entity will be disregarded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Guptill Holding Corp. v. State
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporation may be formed for any legitimate purpose even to merely escape personal liability or to transact business which if conducted by individual would violate usury laws, but incorporations are subject to "tests of honesty and justice" and will be ignored if a perversion of privilege to do business in corporate form.
Document Preview: Proceeding on appeal from an order of the Supreme Court, Special Term, Albany County, Edward S. Conway, J., directing that condemnation award be paid to state in partial satisfaction of tax lien. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Herlihy, P.J., held that state was not entitled to pierce corporate veil and recover, from condemnation award made to corporation for land transferred to it by dominant shareholder, amount due in personal income taxes by such shareholder on theory that corporation and individual were one-and-the-same, where corporation was formed before condemnation, shareholder's control was not used to commit wrong, and there was no showing of fraudulent or illegal activity by corporation bringing claim for damages, and there was no basis for equitable intervention, government not having been injured by any corporate act of shareholder in regard to conduct of his corporate business. Reversed and remitted with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Plumbers and Fitters, Local 761 v. Matt J. Zaich Const. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, doctrine of "piercing corporate veil" is designed to prevent a person from doing injury and then escaping responsibility by hiding behind a corporate shield.
Document Preview: Action by employer against union for unlawful picketing. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Manuel L. Real, J., awarded money damages, including attorneys' fees, and union appealed. The Court of Appeals, Ely, Circuit Judge, held that evidence supported finding that picketed corporation and another corporation, both owned by one man, were separate entities, contrary to assertion of defendant union that picketed corporation should be bound by arbitration clauses in labor contracts that the other corporation had with union, and that where portion of judgment relating to legal fees did not specify amount attributable to one segment of controversy, case would be remanded for supplemental findings of fact on issue, so that parties might be able to reach a stipulated breakdown of the claimed attorney's fees, or for district court to again award attorney's fees. Affirmed in part; remanded for limited proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Hubbard v. Capital Southwest Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Waco.
Headnote: Corporate entity will not be disregarded nor officers or directors held liable on corporate obligations except where corporate entity is used as a sham to perpetrate a fraud, to avoid personal liability, avoid effect of a statute, or in a few other exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: Stockholders' derivative action, in which plaintiffs sought judgment against organizing corporation and joint officers and directors for intercorporate indebtedness. The 68th District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered summary judgment in favor of defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wilson, J., held that where history of organizing and incorporated corporations evidenced constant effort by organizer and its officers to salvage incorporatee and predecessor from insolvency, stockholders of incorporatee were fully informed of steps taken, including intercorporate loans, and actively participated or maintained silence without dissent and inequity or disruption of purpose of legal entity was not otherwise shown, corporate entity would not be disregarded and organizing corporation and joint officers and directors held liable for intercorporate indebtedness, notwithstanding that incorporatee may have been alter ego of organizing corporation....

The Court of Appeals, Murrah, Chief Judge, held that fact that individual defendant was sole owner of corporation was not sufficient factual basis for disregarding corporate entity, and, therefore, individual defendant who advanced funds to finance contract between patentee and corporation was not individually bound by contract...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: First Western Bank & Trust Co. v. Bookasta
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: To apply alter ego doctrine it is essential that showing be made of unity of interest and ownership and promotion of injustice by fiction of corporate separate existence.
Document Preview: Action upon corporation note by bank against corporation and several of its shareholders. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Ernest J. Zack, J., dismissed both counts of complaint and the bank appealed. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Sams v. Redevelopment Authority of City of New Kensington
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate entity or personality will be disregarded only when entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud or defend crime.
Document Preview: Eminent domain case. The Court of Common Pleas, Westmoreland County, David H. Weiss, L. Alexander Sculco and Richard E. McCormick, JJ., rendered judgment and condemnor appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 203 March Term, 1967, Cohen, J., held that where two individuals doing business as partnership owned parcel of land taken by eminent domain and they used this parcel as a scrapyard, and where same individuals owned parcel across the street and a corporation, of which these individuals were sole stockholders, operated foundry on this parcel, assessment of damages as if the two tracts were one parcel could not be allowed, as two separate and distinct legal entities operated each parcel, and the corporate veil would not be pierced to change this result. Reversed and remanded. Eagen, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Bell Oil & Gas Co. v. Allied Chemical Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Courts will not disregard corporate fiction and hold individual officers, directors or stockholders liable on obligations of corporation except where it appears that individuals are using corporate entity as sham to perpetuate fraud, to avoid personal liability, to avoid effect of statute, or in a few other exceptional circumstances.

The Supreme Court, Norvell, J., held that under circumstances, parent corporation was not liable for contract obligations of affiliated corporation, owned by owners of parent corporation, and subsidiary corporation, owned by parent and organized to succeed affiliated corporation, where separate organizations were maintained and plaintiff had not relied on any representation by parent corporation in extending credit and there was no conspiracy, joint venture, or fraud. Reversed and rendered.

Title: Widdicombe v. McGuire

Headnote: While corporate entities may be disregarded where they are made the implement for avoiding clear legislative purpose, they will not be disregarded where those in control have deliberately adopted the corporate form in order to secure its advantages and where no violence to legislative purpose is done by treating the corporate entity as a separate legal person.

Judgment modified and as modified affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Minchen v. Van Trease
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded when corporation is used to perpetrate a fraud, evade an existing legal obligation, achieve or perpetrate a monopoly, protect a crime, justify a wrong, circumvent a statute, and when one corporation exists as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: Action by creditor on promissory notes of corporation, seeking to attach personal liability to sole remaining stockholder. The Court of Civil Appeals, Sam D. Reversed and rendered.

Judgments affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Title: Zubik v. Zubik

Hooper, J., granted petition for review and remanded the matter for granting of the reclamation petition, ordering that former stockholder be allowed to share pro rata with unsecured creditors as to any deficiency in his claim, and trustee appealed. Title: Wooddale, Inc. v. Fidelity & Deposit Co. of Md.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil cannot be removed merely to give litigant advantage at law when, in absence of fraudulent allegations, parties deal at arm's length.
Document Preview: Corporate contractor brought action against bonding company on fidelity bond, and bonding company filed thirdparty complaint against subcontractor. The Court of Appeals, Lay, Circuit Judge, held that subcontractor who as president of corporate contractor from which he allegedly misappropriated funds submitted all bids in name of corporation and who bid only on jobs approved by director and who was subject to control, direction and ultimate discharge of corporation and its directors was an employee of corporation within meaning of fidelity bond notwithstanding subcontractor's dual employment. Title: Farmers Feed & Supply Co. v. U. S.

Title: Pasos v. Ferber
Court: United States District Court M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Fiction of a corporation as an entity distinct from individuals comprising it will be disregarded and the individuals and corporation considered identical whenever justice and public policy demand, and when rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced thereby nor the theory of corporate entity made useless.

The District Court, Sheridan, Chief Judge, held that where health of judgment debtor, a salesman, had become seriously impaired so that defendant was unable to continue as active participant in business, and a corporation was formed in which debtor's wife received 98 percent of the capital stock and the wife, qualified by training and experience, took over active management of corporation which received salesman's franchise and to which commissions on sales were paid, judgment creditors were not entitled to attach commissions owing to corporation on theory that corporation was alter ego of judgment debtor or on theory that there had been fraudulent transfer of assets to corporation which had assumed substantial liabilities of debtor. Reversed and rendered that appellees take nothing by their suit against appellants.

Title: Lewis Trucking Corp. v. Commonwealth
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia.
