Document Preview: In a case which originated as a general creditor's bill, the Chancery Court, Hamilton County, Ray L. Brock, Jr., Chancellor, allowed all claims against surety on statutory Real Estate Agent's and Salesman's Bond except that of bankruptcy trustee, and the trustee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cooper, J., held that where domination of both parent and subsidiary corporation by majority stockholder and principal executive officer of both corporations was so complete that neither had any mind, will or existence of its own, relationship was such that they were to be treated as single entity, for purposes of parent's trustee's claim on subsidiary's bond. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc. v. Atlas
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York, Part III.
Headnote: An exception to concept of corporate entity exists when corporation is used to defraud creditors or evade existing obligations or where corporation is used for purpose which is fraudulent, illegal or contrary to public policy.
Document Preview: Action by judgment creditor to recover the amount of the judgment from defendants. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Nassau County, Part III, Bernard S. Meyer, J., held, inter alia, that where corporate purchaser of realty had been dormant prior to contract to purchase, it had no regularly elected officers or directors and it had no assets, liabilities or income, and vendor did not rely upon third party's credit, vendor which obtained judgment against corporate purchaser could collect such judgment from corporation's president. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Petition of Sheridan
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Organization of corporation to insulate organizer from responsibilities of liability is, standing by itself, no basis for invading corporate entity.
Document Preview: Exceptions to report of a special commissioner appointed to ascertain and appraise value of interest of petitioners for limitation of liability with respect to fund to be surrendered by them. The District Court, Ryan, Chief Judge, held, inter alia, that libelants contending that value of tug which was part of flotilla should have been included in fund with barge, on theory that tug, though operating under different owner was in fact controlled by petitioner failed to establish elements prerequisite for disregard of corporate entity of tug owner of which petitioner was president and in which he owned 350 of 1,000 shares. Report confirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Tarter, Webster & Johnson, Inc. v. Windsor Developers, Inc.
Court: Appellate Department, Superior Court, San Diego County, California.
Headnote: Generally, in order to enforce alter ego theory bad faith must be shown.
Document Preview: Action by wholesale lumber company to foreclose mechanic's liens on residence properties constructed by developer. The San Diego Municipal Court, Robert O. Staniforth, J., rendered judgment for the wholesaler, and the developer appealed. The Superior Court held that wholesaler, which furnished loads for individual houses to retailer which supplied developer's framing contractor, was not entitled to mechanic's liens on individual residence properties even if retailer and framing contractor were but alter ego of individuals organizing both corporations, where neither corporation nor individuals who organized them were parties to foreclosure action. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Roberts' Fish Farm v. Spencer
Court: Supreme Court of Florida.
Headnote: Purpose of corporations is generally to limit liability and serve a business convenience and those who do business in corporate form are entitled to rely on rules of law which protect them against personal liability, unless corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purpose.
Document Preview: Proceeding on claims against two separate corporations and a partnership for workmen's compensation benefits. To review an order of the Florida Industrial Commission which affirmed an order of the deputy commissioner awarding compensation benefits and holding one of the corporations and the partnership jointly liable with corporate employer for payment of such benefits, such corporation and partnership brought certiorari. The Supreme Court, O'Connell, J., held that the Industrial Commission, acting either through the Full Commission or a deputy, had no jurisdiction to disregard legal entities and hold another corporation and partnership jointly liable with corporate employer for payment of compensation benefits on theory that the partnership and corporations were in fact one and not three separate entities. Order quashed and cause remanded for proceedings consistent with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: McKee v. Peterson
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Bad faith is underlying element in cases where corporate entity is justifiably disregarded.
Document Preview: Automobile seller's action against chattel mortgagee and others. The Superior Court, County of San Mateo, Edmund Scott, J., entered a judgment in favor of the mortgagee and the seller and one of the individual defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Bray, P. J., held that seller of automobile to dealer, which gave check that was dishonored, was estopped to claim ownership of automobile as against bona fide mortgagee who had relied on indicia of ownership, except possession of automobile, furnished by seller to dealer which mortgagee had no reason to suspect would give a check that would be dishonored. Judgment reversed and cause remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Mull v. Colt Co.
Court: United States District Court S. D. New York.
Headnote: A corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity generally until sufficient reason to the contrary appears, but, when notion of legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: Action against stockholders in taxicab companies, taxicab companies, manufacturer of taxicab, and automobile dealer for injuries sustained by plaintiff when struck by taxicab. On motions to dismiss the complaint, the District Court, Edelstein, J., held that complaint, which alleged that 100 corporations each owning two taxicabs and carrying the minimum amount of insurance required by state law were formed in violation of police department regulations to enable stockholders and the corporations to defraud fraud the public and that the corporations had inadequate capitalization, stated sufficient grounds to pierce the corporate veil and stated a claim against individual stockholders and the corporations holding the cabs, which were garaged, maintained and operated centrally. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Goldberg
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity distinct from individual stockholders will be disregarded when justice or public policy demands and innocent parties' rights are not prejudiced or fiction made useless.
Document Preview: Prosecution for conspiracy and attempted evasion of income taxes due from defendant personally and from corporations under his control, in which defendant filed post-trial motions challenging sufficiency of the indictment and the evidence and asserting trial and procedural errors. The District Court, Kraft, J., held that verdict of defendant's guilt on counts of indictment charging attempted evasion of income taxes due by defendant individually, was not repugnant to verdict of guilty on other counts of indictment charging attempted evasion of taxes due by corporations wholly owned by defendnt. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Houston-American Life Ins. Co. v. Tate
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity will be disregarded: where fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud; where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; where corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading an existing legal obligation; where corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; where corporate fiction is used to circumvent statute; and where corporate fiction is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: Action by husband and wife against finance company, life insurance company, and their common holding company for damages on account of wrongful conduct in seeking to enforce usurious contract. Wife as executrix was substituted for husband upon suggestion of his death. The 44th District Court, Dallas County, Sam B. Hall, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Tirey, J., held that the husband's cause of action for exemplary damages survived, and that the judgment was proper except that exemplary damages awarded were excessive. Judgment reformed in conformity with remittitur and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Ivy Hall Apartments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate fiction will be disregarded and corporation and individuals comprising it considered as identical whenever justice or public policy demand and when rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced thereby or theory of corporate entity made useless.
Document Preview: Action to foreclose a real estate mortgage and an accompanying chattel mortgage, wherein the president and sole stockholder of corporate mortgagor claimed reimbursement for advances made to mortgagor and for the value and rental of some of the furniture, claimed by him individually, which was located on the mortgaged premises. The District Court, Kraft, J., held, inter alia, that president and sole stockholder, claiming right to reimbursement for advances made to corporate mortgagor was, at best, nothing more than an unsecured, general creditor and that no funds were available for payment of such claim. Claims disallowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Bonnar-Vawter, Inc. v. Johnson
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded when used to cover fraud or illegality or to justify a wrong, but it will not be disregarded when to do so would promote injustice, give unfair advantage, or contravene public policy.
Document Preview: Appeal by complaint from an assessment of use tax, interest and penalty. The case was reported from the Superior Court, Kennebec County, for decision upon the complaint, answers, and agreed statement of facts. The Supreme Judicial Court, Siddall, J., held that printing plates manufactured by wholly owned subsidiary in another state for use in parent corporation's printing business in Maine were purchased by parent corporation from subsidiary at retail sale in ordinary course of seller's business and were not consumed or destroyed in printing process within meaning of exclusionary clause of sales and use tax law, R.S.1954, c. 17, § 2, and that hence use of such plates by parent corporation in Maine was taxable under R.S.1954, c. 17, § 4. Appeal to Superior Court denied and case remanded for decree denying appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: City Bank Farmers Trust Co. v. Macfadden
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To hold a membership corporation liable for obligations of a controlling member, as his mere alter ego, there must be a finding that the corporate form existed as a mere subterfuge and was used by him for a purpose which was fraudulent, illegal, or contrary to public policy.
Document Preview: Action for a judicial settlement of the account of plaintiff as trustee under a deed of trust. From an interlocutory judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term, Edgar J. Nathan, Jr., J., 25 Misc.2d 125, 198 N.Y.S.2d 782, the defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Eager, J., held that the evidence did not establish that transfers of funds and property by husband in his lifetime to a foundation were fraudulent as to the former wife or in violation of the Debtor and Creditor Law and that a prior New Jersey judgment was not res judicata. Judgment modified. Stevens and McNally, JJ., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: In re Gibraltor Amusements, Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Courts will pierce corporate veil when notion of legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, and will disregard separate entity where it has been used as "front" or "mere conduit".
Document Preview: Proceeding to review an order of Hon. Louis J. Castellano, Referee in Bankruptcy, adjudicating a debtor a bankrupt on the petition of creditors. From an order of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, John R. Bartels, J., 187 F.Supp. 931, partially sustaining and partially denying the petition, and confirming the referee's adjudication, the bankrupt appealed. The Court of Appeals, J. Joseph Smith, Circuit Judge, held that a creditor corporation's wholly owned subsidiary, to which the corporation had assigned claims against the debtor long before the filing of the petition, could be counted as one of the required number of petitioning creditors where the corporation and the subsidiary had strictly honored the corporate form as to assets and in intercorporate transactions, and there was no showing of attempted subversion of the Bankruptcy Act. Affirmed. Friendly, Circuit Judge, dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Post Sign Co. v. Jemc's, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section.
Headnote: Separate entity of corporation will be disregarded upon showing that corporation is mere sham or dummy or where necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: General creditor's proceeding. The Knox County Chancery, Chas. E. Dawson, Chancellor, entered decree that sole stockholder's purchase money deed of trust note was tainted with usury and unjust enrichment and that receiver of corporation which purchased stockholder's equity in property encumbered by deed of trust was entitled to have indebtedness purged of such usury, and vendor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Worley, Special Judge, held that receiver of corporation, which was legally organized, functioned at all times as separate legal entity, and took title to stockholder's equity in realty, subject to lien indebtedness, after all creditors' claims had accrued was not entitled to have transaction whereby stockholder and vendor created the lien indebtedness purged of usury for benefit of corporate creditors on theory that vendor was unjustly enriched or that corporate entity should be disregarded. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Morgan Plan Co. v. Vellianitis
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: A court of equity will look through form to substance and will declare corporate setup a sham or subterfuge where substantially all of its stockholders organized it for personal purpose, subversive of rights of others.
Document Preview: Proceedings on bill in equity for declaratory judgment as to rights of parties under certain subleases. From a decree of the Circuit Court, Mobile County, W. C. Taylor, J., sustaining a demurrer to the bill, complainant appealed. The Supreme Court, Merrill, J., held that if terms of sublease have given sublessee a similar option in event that lessee-sublessor renews his own lease, lessee-sublessor cannot evade his obligation to renew sublease at instance of sublessee when lessee-sublessor renews his own lease or takes a new lease. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Islip Mach. Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. New York.
Headnote: Court will not permit a fictitious personality to be used to evade or defeat a public duty or statutory obligation by the use of the corporate form.
Document Preview: Action under the Walsh-Healey Act for damages for breach of contract arising out of underpayment of wages on a government contract brought against the corporate contracting party and the corporate president who was not a signatory on the contract but whose liability was predicated upon a finding that he was in effect a party responsible for the breach of the contract. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, Bartels, J., held that where the corporation and the president were one and the same as contracting parties they could be held jointly and severally responsible. Judgment for the government.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: O'Neill v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation is to be treated as an entity separate from individuals who own it, but corporate structure may be disregarded where purpose of creation of corporation was not a business purpose and creation was not followed by any business activity, but where corporation was created for a business activity or creation is followed by business activity, corporation must be recognized as a separate entity.
Document Preview: Proceeding by taxpayers for review of decision of Tax Court of United States holding they were liable for certain income taxes in years 1951 and 1952 and for an addition to their tax for failure to file declaration of estimated tax in year 1952. The Court of Appeals, Kilkenny, District Judge, held that evidence sustained finding that advances to corporation by taxpayers, who contended that they were entitled to take a deduction in year 1952 for loss sustained as result of investments in corporation, were contributions to capital and were not loans and that taxpayer failed to prove reasonable cause for his failure to file a declaration of estimated tax for year 1952. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Yankoviak v. Michigan Public Service Commission
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be recognized by courts and the law will be administered accordingly, unless it appears that corporation is functioning in such a manner as to violate or at least evade the law or contravene public policy.
Document Preview: Suit by common carrier by motor vehicle to set aside order of public service commission authorizing contract motor carrier of petroleum and petroleum products to extend its operation, wherein the contract carrier intervened. The Circuit Court for Ingham County, In Chancery, Louis C. Coash, P. J., entered a decree affirming the commission's order, and plaintiff appeals. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that basic findings of fact, made by commission in support of its order, including finding that proposed operation, involving a new service in the area, would not impair the efficient public service of any common or contract carrier then adequately serving the area, were supported by sufficient competent evidence. Decree affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Gagnon v. Speback
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Fiction of corporation as an entity distinct from the aggregate of individuals comprising it was designed to serve convenience and justice, and the fiction will be disregarded and the individuals and corporation considered as identical, whenever justice or public policy demand and when rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced thereby nor theory of corporate entity made useless.
Document Preview: Action in equity to have conveyance of land to corporation by incorporators declared fraudulent and void as to plaintiff's rights against defendant incorporators. The Court of Common Pleas of Indiana County, at No. 1, March Term, 1954, Edwin M. Clark, J., entered orders and final decree in favor of plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Nos. 30, 31, 32, March Term, 1957, Arnold, J., held that the evidence sustained finding that gratuitous conveyance to corporation was fraudulent as to holder of judgment entered against grantors on their judgment note after conveyance. Decree affirmed. Musmanno, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Automotriz Del Golfo De California S. A. De C. V. v. Resnick
Court: Supreme Court of California, in Bank.
Headnote: Generally, conditions under which a corporate entity may be disregarded vary according to the circumstances of each case, but two requirements for disregard of the corporate entity are that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Action by foreign corporation for balance due on price of automobiles allegedly sold to defendants. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Clarence M. Hanson, J., entered judgment for foreign corporation, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Gibson, C. J., held that evidence was sufficient to sustain trial court's conclusions that defendants had failed to meet burden of proving that the sale was an intrastate transaction and that evidence was sufficient to sustain trial court's finding that defendants were doing business as individuals, rather than through a corporation. Judgment affirmed. Opinions, 292 P.2d 578,297 P.2d 109,298 P.2d 33, vacated. Carter, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Wells v. Hiskett
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In order for courts to disregard the corporate entity, it must appear that the corporate cloak is used by those in control as a sham to perpetrate fraud, justify wrong or defeat public convenience.
Document Preview: Action by children of first marriage of wife in trespass to try title and in the alternative to claim that property was community property of the wife and her second husband or was acquired under circumstances giving rise to trust in favor of the wife and for an accounting. Judgment for plaintiffs in the District Court, Gregg County, Fred Erisman, J., and the defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Davis, J., held that the evidence failed to establish that a corporation organized by the husband and another to engage in oil operations was in fraud of the wife, that the corporate entity could not be disregarded, that findings of the jury that acquisition of property by the corporation resulted from the efforts of the wife were against the evidence, and that the property claimed was not held in trust for the wife and remained the separate property of the husband as a matter of law. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Wells v. Hiskett
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: A corporate entity may not be disregarded simply because it stands as a bar to a litigant's recovery of property.
Document Preview: Action by children of first marriage of wife in trespass to try title and in the alternative to claim that property was community property of the wife and her second husband or was acquired under circumstances giving rise to trust in favor of the wife and for an accounting. Judgment for plaintiffs in the District Court, Gregg County, Fred Erisman, J., and the defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Davis, J., held that the evidence failed to establish that a corporation organized by the husband and another to engage in oil operations was in fraud of the wife, that the corporate entity could not be disregarded, that findings of the jury that acquisition of property by the corporation resulted from the efforts of the wife were against the evidence, and that the property claimed was not held in trust for the wife and remained the separate property of the husband as a matter of law. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Allied Stevedoring Corp.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity, but, when notion of legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: Corporation and two individual defendants were indicted for fraudulent attempt to evade corporate income taxes. Corporation moved to have indictment dismissed on ground that, because federal tax lien filed against corporate assets, corporation was without funds to retain accountants, lawyers, and other personnel required to prepare its defense to assist during trial of the indictment. The District Court, Irving R. Kaufman, J., held that, where corporation and two corporate officers were indicted for fraudulent attempt to evade corporate income taxes, and notice of federal tax lien filed against corporate assets allegedly left corporation without funds to retain accountants, lawyers, and other personnel required to prepare its defense and to assist during trial of the indictment, corporation would not be entitled to have indictment dismissed in view of fact that attorney representing corporation admitted that he would continue his representation even if motion were denied. Motion...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Warren v. Motion Picture Mach. Operators New Castle Local No. 451 of Intern. Alliance of Theatrical Stage Emp. and Moving Picture Mach. Operators of U. S. and Canada
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The corporate entity will be disregarded when justice or public policy demands it; the rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced, and the theory of corporate entity is not made useless thereby.
Document Preview: Proceeding by family-owned theatre corporation against projectionists' union for damages and injunctive relief against picketing. The Court of Common Pleas of Lawrence County at No. 3, September Term, 1955, in Equity, John G. Lamoree, J., denied the plaintiff relief on the ground that a bona fide labor dispute existed, which was not enjoinable. The theater appealed. The Supreme Court, No. 207, March Term, 1955, Musmanno, J., held that where family corporation, which owned drive-in theater, employed stockholder-member of family as non-union projectionist, in violation of terms of contract between corporation and projectionists' union, a labor dispute was involved, within statute prohibiting the issuance of injunctions in labor disputes, except upon certain conditions. Order affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Hudson Minneapolis, Inc. v. Hudson Motor Car Co.
Court: United States District Court D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Generally, courts will ignore the fiction of corporate entity only with caution, and when circumstances justify it, and when it is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: Action was brought against foreign corporation. The foreign corporation made a motion to quash service of two summonses and to dismiss the action, on ground of insufficiency of service of process, and therefore lack of jurisdiction over the person of the foreign corporation. The District Court, Nordbye, Chief Judge, held that subsidiary corporation, which handled sales of automobiles manufactured by foreign parent corporation, was not parent's agent, on which service could be made. Service of summons quashed and action dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Barium Steel Corp. v. Wiley
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts can go behind the corporate entity whenever justice or public policy demand it and when the rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced thereby nor the theory of corporate entity made useless.
Document Preview: Action for breach of warranties contained in agreement of sale of stock by defendants to plaintiff. From adverse decree of Court of Common Pleas, Lancaster County, as of July Term, 1950, No. 15, Oliver S. Schaeffer, P. J., both plaintiff and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Nos. 254, 255, 268, January Term, 1953, Bell, J., held that corporate-buyer, to which sellers had made promise to pay percentage of any deficiency assessments made against purchased corporation, could recover from sellers even though it was buyer's corporate grandchild, formed to take over assets of purchased corporation, which was legally liable for, and actually satisfied, such assessments. Judgment of court below reversed and verdict of jury reinstated and judgment entered thereon. Jones, Stearne and Chidsey, JJ., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Cooper v. Industrial Commission
Court: Supreme Court of Arizona.
Headnote: Generally, when a corporate form is urged or carried on for an intent not within the reason and purpose for which it is allowed by law, the form should be disregarded, but where a corporation is operated and maintained for the purpose for which it was incorporated and not as a mere shield of stockholders, the corporate form cannot be disregarded.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation proceeding. The Industrial Commission of Arizona denied petitioner compensation as an injured employee, and employee appealed by certiorari. The Supreme Court, La Prade, J., held that where carpenter was employed to do carpentry work in employer's home, and employer was not engaged in construction business, the employee was a person whose employment was casual and not in the usual course of trade, business, or occupation of the employer, and employer was not subject to the Workmen's Compensation Law. Award affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: Green v. Equitable Powder Mfg. Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Arkansas, Fort Smith Division.
Headnote: Courts will ignore the fiction of corporate legal entity when circumstances justify it, and when it is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: Herman Green brought an action against Equitable Powder Manufacturing Company, a corporation, for personal injuries received as result of a delayed explosion of dynamite. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff's amended complaint. The District Court, John E. Miller, J., held that plaintiff could maintain an action for negligence, notwithstanding defendant was not liable for any breach of warranty. Motion overruled, except in so far as any allegations of liability due to breach of warranty were concerned.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: McIver v. Norman
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon.
Headnote: While for all ordinary purposes, a corporation is regarded as a legal entity separate and distinct from stockholders where the notion of legal entity is used to defeat convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: Suit by James W. McIver against Willmar A. Norman, also known as William S. Norman, for the dissolution of a joint adventure, an accounting and other relief. The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, James W. Crawford, J., held that the plaintiff was barred by laches, and that the case fell within the principle of speculative delay and entered a decree dismissing the suit, and the plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Lusk, C. J., held that plaintiff did not abandon his right to or his interest in the joint adventure, that plaintiff was not barred by laches, that the principle of speculative delay did not apply, and that plaintiff was entitled to an accounting and reversed the decree and remanded the cause for further proceedings. See also, Or., 205 P.2d 137.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1036 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Hudgins-Dize Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: The corporate form cannot be used to evade or defeat public policy or lawful ends of legislation, and courts will tear away the corporate veil whenever it is used to evade a statute or modify its intent.
Document Preview: Action by the United States of America against Hudgins-Dize Company, Inc., and others to recover as liquidated damages the amount of the underpayment of overtime wages for alleged violations of the Walsh-Healey Act, Secs. 1-11, as amended, 41 U.S.C.A. §§ 35-45.  On motions for summary judgment. Decision in accordance with opinion.
